document_title: Sex differences in muscle health in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments in rats
summary_full: This study investigated how biological sex and sex steroid hormones influence muscle atrophy in male and female rats exposed to simulated microgravity (0g) and partial gravity (0.4g) for 28 days. Rats underwent either castration/ovariectomy or sham surgeries. Results showed that females experienced greater losses in muscle size and strength (dorsiflexion, plantar flexion) compared to males in both 0g and 0.4g conditions. These sex-based differences persisted even after gonadectomy, suggesting they are not solely dependent on sex steroid hormones. The findings indicate that females may be more susceptible to musculoskeletal aberrations in reduced gravity environments, potentially requiring sex-specific interventions for astronauts.
key_findings: Female rats exhibited greater loss of muscle size and strength (dorsiflexion and plantar flexion) compared to male rats in both simulated microgravity (0g) and partial gravity (0.4g) environments.
These sex differences in muscle atrophy were observed regardless of the presence or absence of sex steroid hormones (castration/ovariectomy vs. sham surgery).
Females showed greater loss in leg girth and muscle cross-sectional area, particularly at 0.4g.
Muscle fiber cross-sectional area, especially type I and hybrid fibers, was reduced more significantly in females than males at 0.4g.
While males showed some increases in dorsiflexion parameters in 0g, females consistently lost more plantar flexion power in both 0g and 0.4g conditions.
The study suggests that females may require additional or tailored interventions to mitigate musculoskeletal loss during spaceflight.
future_research_fields: Development of sex-specific interventions to mitigate muscle loss in female astronauts.
Investigating the role of chromosomal makeup (XX vs. XY) in sex differences in unloading-induced muscle atrophy.
Studying muscle recovery timelines in females after exposure to reduced gravity.
Exploring the interaction of other spaceflight stressors (radiation, sleep disturbances) with gravity on sex-based muscle health.
Evaluating the efficacy of different exercise modalities as countermeasures for female astronauts.

conclusions: Female rats experience greater muscle size and strength loss compared to males in simulated micro- and partial-gravity environments, and these differences are independent of sex steroid hormones. This suggests that females may be inherently more susceptible to musculoskeletal deconditioning in reduced gravity, necessitating the development of sex-specific countermeasures for astronauts.
impact_statement: This study highlights a critical sex-based vulnerability in muscle health during simulated spaceflight, informing the need for tailored interventions to ensure the safety and efficacy of female astronauts in future space missions.
